We live in a culture that has made an idol of the self. Other people are seen as a means to enrich our own lives, or else just a nuisance. I can't think of any other era in history where so many would wear the moniker of "I hate people" as a badge of honor. You have people who put all of their affection into their animals, because having to consider the needs and wants of a complex equal is too much emotional effort. So it's no surprise that the concept of parenthood is so frequently met with recoil and horror, since it requires so much sacrifice for so little material reward. You have to deal with what people see as a very inconvenient screaming ball of flesh for 18 years that will likely bring you all kinds of frustration and grief, and if your primary focus is on self-actualization and living an unfettered lifestyle to pursue your own whims, parenthood will appear to be a shackle.
Our entire culture is at its root anti-child and anti-family, since it's anti-sacrifice. It's shocking how many people proudly declare how they don't want children, even in Catholic circles. Typically this has been an adolescent response to a fear of responsibility that people have grown out of, but much like the single-minded pursuit of the feeling of falling in love rather than accepting the sacrifices of living a life of love, people are encouraged to cling to this selfishness well into adulthood and not truly grow into a person who understands that responsibility extends beyond the self. While it is true that not all people are called to marriage and having children, the sentiment of revulsion toward the idea of marriage or children is not a healthy one even for a person called to celibacy. Even St. Francis felt a draw toward the married life.
We are a culture mired in a specific sickness involving the family, and it's the root of many of our other issues. It needs to be rooted out and replaced with a Catholic view of the person and the family in order to begin eliminating these problems.

It's not as obvious as you'd think. But regardless, the point I think OP is trying to make is precisely that belief systems called "religions" aren't similar enough to merit categorization when discussing their effects, validity, etc. As an umbrella term, it's not particularly useful.

Not just in other religions, that's the point. In any cosmology, ethical philosophy, or what have you, people that subscribe to it think that they're right and everyone else is wrong. Whether or not the view comes from a religious perspective is irrelevant as to whether or not it's true.

This is something that we have a big problem with in the western world. There's an idea that religion is a subjective belief that should only apply to those who agree to follow it. We've placed an arbitrary distiction between religion and everything else so that when we don't like something any more we can dismiss it as part of a religion and therefore not applicable to the rest of society. When the majority agreed that marriage was between a man and a woman, there was no mention of it being a religious idea, since nearly every culture of many different religions held the same view. Now that popular opinion has shifted the opposite way, it's been deemed a religious view, and thus easily dismissable by those who don't agree. There's an association of religion with irrational belief that only applies to the person believing it.
This allows people to draw an imaginary distinction between belief systems, cosmologies, ethical frameworks, etc. by calling some of them "religions" and thus permissible to ignore. That's why you hear so many people say that religion has no place in the public square, or in politics, and that religion causes wars. It's easy to group all the things you don't like under a common umbrella, when the only thing they actually have in common is a belief in the supernatural (if even that). It's a hard-coded bias toward naturalism and materialism that has no logical backing, just a disdainful sneer toward other beliefs.
So no, I don't think it's particularly useful to group all religions together in a discussion, unless you're studying their effect on culture or something. But in practical terms, whether a belief comes from a religion or not is unrelated to whether it is right or wrong. That should be the focus. Secular humanism deserves no greater place in our law than Islam or any false religion, just because they have the moniker "religion" and it doesn't.
